column1: The clouds that visit its sky reveal themselves beyond the one great rise
column5: and sink beyond that other. But the plains above which they have traveled and the Weald to which they go
column6: the people of the valley cannot see and hardly recall. The wind
column8: is no longer a gale from the salt
column10: an inland breeze; and those whose blood was nourished here feel in that wind the fruitfulness of our orchards and all the life that all things draw from the air. In this place
column12: I pushed through a fringe of beeches that made a complete screen between me and the world
column13: and I came to a glade called "No Man's Land". I climbed beyond it
column14: and I was surprised and glad
column15: because from the ridge of that glade
column16: I saw the sea. To this place very lately I returned.
